header.rec_loc: Living Room in bungalow in Snettisham; speakers 2 and 3’s home.
header.relationships: Close family, partners, very close friends
header.topics: Potholing, car dumping in caves, the dinner, TV, cars, breakdowns, tea round, special necklaces, calling in sick, crumble, pedant/pheasant, moorhens/coots, village ponds, plenums, the countryside, London, Credenhill Chinese Restaurant, antiques in Hereford and Leominster and TV programmes on antiques, yards sales/car boot sales, throwing away antiques, Ebay, old radios, TV sets, washing machines, records and record players, cables, clothes, value, gold conductors and radio frequencies, broadband, uses of precious metals, precious stones, birth stones, jewellery, anniversary presents, hair going white, dog hair jumper, unusual ways of keeping ashes and locks of hair, Colleen Rooney’s afterbirth pills, superstitions, dreams, ANON’s school days, literacy and mathematics in children today, jobs, finances.
header.activity: Chatting to Grandparents and parents over and after dinner.

body.u: so what were these people potholing caving?
and they were going down for a nice bit of potholing?
yeah and they were all these cars they took photos of them there was loads of them all piled well right up and er you know all down there
wouldn't get past you know failed their MOTs or been in crashes and
and someone's just been chucking them down in the cave
for years that's very naughty I think that's fly-tipping
can I take your plate grandad or?
it's alright I jumped on that grenade
took one for the team didn't you dad?

we've been watching this programme where every day every time they had they then take people on hol to r you know replicate a holiday they had when they was a child and they always had to have an old car what they went in you know and er and I said to him I remember that when you first came to ours when you first started going out with you had an old Ford

a mill pond not a village pond?

a mill pond is in fact in plenum
a mill pond it's a kind of plenum
it's a kind of plenum? what's plenum?
would you pass me that cup
instead of running a mill directly from the river

you keep some water in a pond so you'd have a constant flow through the mill that the water tops up so that the wa if the river runs fast or slow it doesn't matter the pond always feeds the mill rather than the river feeding it
and that's what a plenum is?
yes it's a reserve of something a plenum chamber in a fuel injected car for example or a turbo charged car keeps a reservoir of pressurised air to reduce lag on the turbo
and it's called the plenum chamber

like you could care even less
there you are you should learn something new every day

one function of the plenum is
so the mill pond is higher than the mill and therefore has a higher pressure than the water at the mill

yeah well I mean it's the same with anything though I mean when we first got married we had an old erm Hoover twin tub and he he'd be at work and I'd think oh god now what's gone wrong? and the blooming erm there wa in the back room this spin tub was a sort of layer loop thing you know what you'd put the

oh that's gotta have a new circuit board oh cos that thermostat's gone or this has gone oh my god

it's what t in the old days of TV repair that's what you'd call an unskilled TV repairman he's a bottle changer he'd come in with a big box of valves and he'd just keep changing valves until the telly started working

and you used to call them bottle changers didn't diagnose the problem just swapped out the valves until it started working which is what the majority of people do now they go oh well the fault's on this board so I'm gonna change the board not gonna find out which component has gone wrong on the board they just throw the whole board away a new board a new TV board for that is probably two hundred quid where you can fix it for fifty P mm

but when I was little you know I mean we had no electric in our cottage when I was small not for years and we had this big old radio on the windowsill and you used to have an accumulator to run it off you know

and used to come round from the the from market and you used to get all sorts off him paraffin for the stoves and all that and you'd you'd pay sixpence for a week for this accumulator and he's give you a new one and take the old one away you know
just put it on the back and he'd have a little carrying on thing and we had a record player wind up one

so the warmness of the fuzzy sound

monster monster cables you can get a cable to run from your TV to your DVD player your HDMI cable you can go and buy one of those and you can get one in a pound shop for a pound or you can go to somewhere that sells monster cables and you can buy exactly the same cable for four hundred and fifty pounds
do you know what the difference between them is?

one costs four hundred and fifty pounds and the other one costs a pound there is no difference it's a digital signal so it either works or it doesn't there's no difference in quality in sound quality or picture quality

whatsoever because it's digital it either works or it doesn't work there's no grey area in between there's no improvement in sound quality or picture quality or anything like that it works or it doesn't so if you pay a pound for it brilliant if you pay four hundred and fifty quid for it I'd like to meet you and you can become one of my customers and

and you know I'll I'll put a little knob on the front of your computer that'll go up to eleven so it goes faster than everyone else's computer and I'll charge you four thousand pounds for that it'll just be a little knob that's not connected to anything but you'll think it goes faster
and I'll make four thousand pounds out of you thank you very much
but it's the same with anything isn't it? clothes anything or some people will pay thousands for something you can get at another shop for a tenner and have just as good
it's just all these ppeople who have got money what brag don't they? I've got so much money and I

but it's a that's a subjective thing though isn't it? I mean you know you you might wanna pay more for something that has I dunno a a higher thread count you know a cotton with a higher thread count for example

that is undoubtedly a better quality than something you'd get out of Primark or or or or Matalan or something like that and iit will probably last longer it's probably put together a bit better and you're paying more for that but when you're talking about the actual physics of a cable there is no d iif it works it works exactly the same as the one pound cable as a four hundred and fifty pound cable that is entirely objective
the you have to be an a complete imbecile to believe otherwise

mm yeah I was wondering about the gold and silver tone thing because I thought it was to do with like electric guitars and stuff and it was to do with the electronics part of it but I know that you have silver band and brass band
mm it may may just be a term they use for different sound processes that er that it goes through
I thought it was the actual precious metals though
no I mean gold gold is used in connectors

because gold has a very low electrical resistance and it doesn't tarnish so it's really good for high frequency stuff I'm not talking ab not audio frequency I'm talking about radio frequency because radio frequencies tend to go round the outside of the conductor whereas low frequencies and DC goes through the whole conductor the high frequency though tends to go on the outside now if you've got corrosion round the outside that's gonna attenuate the higher frequencies cos they've got they've got a resistive path to go through which is why er the er broadband for example erm it's er it's on a standard copper pair so if that copper pair is sheathed normally it's been it's oxygen-free and you know

your actual broadband signal is a high frequency signal that comes down that so the voice bbasically your voice signal comes through the middle of the wire a s a solid copper wire but you know broadband internet signal is modulated at a much higher frequency and that tends by its nature to go around the outside of the cable which is fine on a sheathed copper cable because it's nice shiny copper and it works you go somewhere like Milton Keynes new city they put in aluminium wires for the telephones

in the nineteen sixties when they built it because it was cheaper easier to use lighter ththere was no there was no downside with it it was great and it was brilliant for for telephony but the problem with aluminium as soon the instant it comes into contact with air it oxidises so you couldn't get broadband in Milton Keynes cos it was aluminium wires
so they had to replace all the aluminium
they couldn't have foreseen that in the sixties
but all different metals have certain properties don't they?
I mean that's why they use copper in electric cable and all that type of thing isn't it?
it depends what you're using it for
